additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}

name: Midland Tender (Old)

name: LNWR Tender
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}

name: LNER Tender
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}

name: GWR Tender
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}

name: Non-corridor carriage
bio: Non-corridor carriages allow greater seating density, at the cost of passenger comfort.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{YELLOW}10% Penalty for long distance travel{}{SILVER}Non-corridor carriages allow greater seating density, at the cost of passenger comfort.

name: BR Mk1 suburban carriage
bio: BR built many suburban MK1 carriages with no gangways, although typically only one or two would be used per train across most of the country.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{YELLOW}10% Penalty for long distance travel{}{SILVER}BR built many suburban MK1 carriages with no gangways, although typically only one or two would be used per train across most of the country.

name: BR Mk2F carriage
bio: The Mark 2F was the final development of the Mark 2 carriage, introducing many features which would be used on the Mark 3 Intercity carriages.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}The Mark 2F was the final development of the Mark 2 carriage, introducing many features which would be used on the Mark 3 Intercity carriages.

name: CAF Mk5A carriage
bio: The Mark 5A was built for loco-hauled services on the TransPennine Express, but was withdrawn barely four years after introduction.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{YELLOW}20% Bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}The Mark 5A was built for loco-hauled services on the TransPennine Express, but was withdrawn barely four years after introduction.

name: Preserved Clerestory carriage
bio: The first standard gauge preservation railway in the UK was the Bluebell Railway, opened in 1960. Preservation lines are limited to 25mph.
brake_text: {YELLOW}Preserved railway bonus: passengers pay more when hauled by old locomotives{}
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.6 tiles{}{YELLOW}Preserved railway bonus: passengers pay more when hauled by old locomotives{}{SILVER}The first standard gauge preservation railway in the UK was the Bluebell Railway, opened in 1960. Preservation lines are limited to 25mph.

name: Preserved BR Mk1 carriage
bio: The ubiquity of the BR Mk1 carriage has made it a mainstay of preserved railways across the UK.
brake_text: {YELLOW}Preserved railway bonus: passengers pay more when hauled by old locomotives{}
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{YELLOW}Preserved railway bonus: passengers pay more when hauled by old locomotives{}{SILVER}The ubiquity of the BR Mk1 carriage has made it a mainstay of preserved railways across the UK.

name: Torpedo car
bio: Torpedo cars haul molten metal directly from furnaces, meaning it does not have to be processed to an intermediate form and melted again.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{YELLOW}10% Bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}Torpedo cars haul molten metal directly from furnaces, meaning it does not have to be processed to an intermediate form and melted again.

name: Forrester Single
bio: George Forrester and Company built the first passenger tank locomotive to enter service. They were supplied to multiple railways in both tank and tender forms.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}George Forrester and Company built the first passenger tank locomotive to enter service. They were supplied to multiple railways in both tank and tender forms.

name: GWR 2-2-2 "Star"
bio: The first GWR Star class was typical of a 2-2-2 "single" passenger locomotive. They were given common names of stars, such as "Dog Star" and "Shooting Star"
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.6 tiles{}{SILVER}The first GWR Star class was typical of a 2-2-2 "single" passenger locomotive. They were given common names of stars, such as "Dog Star" and "Shooting Star"

name: GWR 4-2-2 "Iron Duke"
bio: The Iron Duke class was powerful and very fast for its time. Although both leading axles were rigidly mounted, the wide curves and broad gauge of the GWR's track made this less of a problem.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.6 tiles{}{SILVER}The Iron Duke class was powerful and very fast for its time. Although both leading axles were rigidly mounted, the wide curves and broad gauge of the GWR's track made this less of a problem.

name: LNWR Precedent Class
bio: F.W. Webb's Precedent class was an express passenger locomotive. A large part of the class was given numbers and names of previously withdrawn locomotives, giving it a fragmented numbering scheme.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{SILVER}F.W. Webb's Precedent class was an express passenger locomotive. A large part of the class was given numbers and names of previously withdrawn locomotives, giving it a fragmented numbering scheme.

name: Midland Railway 156 Class
bio: The Midland 156 class had a long career. It started as an express engine but as power outputs and speeds on the mainline increased it was relegated to increasingly minor duties, ending up being used on small branch lines.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{SILVER}The Midland 156 class had a long career. It started as an express engine but as power outputs and speeds on the mainline increased it was relegated to increasingly minor duties, ending up being used on small branch lines.

name: GNR Stirling 4-2-2
bio: Patrick Stirling's "singles" (also known as "eight footers" due to the large driving wheels) were designed to haul heavy express trains.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}Patrick Stirling's "singles" (also known as "eight footers" due to the large driving wheels) were designed to haul heavy express trains.

name: LNWR Improved Precedent Class
bio: The Improved Precedent was built to replace the existing Precedent class locomotives, being classed as a "renewal" as it gave an advantageous tax situation. Some Precedents were also rebuilt as Improved Precedents, these having different-sized frames to the wholly new locomotives.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{SILVER}The Improved Precedent was built to replace the existing Precedent class locomotives, being classed as a "renewal" as it gave an advantageous tax situation. Some Precedents were also rebuilt as Improved Precedents, these having different-sized frames to the wholly new locomotives.

name: GNR C1 Small Boiler
bio: Henry Ivatt introduced the 4-4-2 Atlantic type to the UK with this design, nicknamed "Klondyke" after the peak of the Klondike Gold Rush of the previous year.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}Henry Ivatt introduced the 4-4-2 Atlantic type to the UK with this design, nicknamed "Klondyke" after the peak of the Klondike Gold Rush of the previous year.

name: GWR 3001 "Achilles"
bio: William Dean's 3001 class was the last of the GWR's 2-2-2 singles. They were rebuilt early on with a 4-2-2 layout to prevent derailments caused by the heavy front axle load.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{SILVER}William Dean's 3001 class was the last of the GWR's 2-2-2 singles. They were rebuilt early on with a 4-2-2 layout to prevent derailments caused by the heavy front axle load.

name: LSWR F9 "Bug"
bio: The F9 was Dugald Drummond's personal locomotive, allowing him to travel across the LSWR for inspections. After Drummond it only saw occasional use at Southampton Docks.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.5 tiles{}{SILVER}The F9 was Dugald Drummond's personal locomotive, allowing him to travel across the LSWR for inspections. After Drummond it only saw occasional use at Southampton Docks.

name: Hawthorn Leslie 0-4-0ST
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{SILVER}

name: GER Class A55 "Decapod"
bio: GER's prototype Decapod was built to outperform low speed acceleration of electric locomotives, to prevent a rival electric railway being approved by Parliament.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.5 tiles{}{SILVER}GER's prototype Decapod was built to outperform low speed acceleration of electric locomotives, to prevent a rival electric railway being approved by Parliament.

name: GWR 3700 "City" Class
additional_text: {SILVER}

name: GWR "Great Bear"
bio: The Great Bear was a single locomotive, the first 4-6-2 "Pacific" type built in the UK, which served as the GWR's flagship until 1922 despite disappointing performance and low route availability.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{SILVER}The Great Bear was a single locomotive, the first 4-6-2 "Pacific" type built in the UK, which served as the GWR's flagship until 1922 despite disappointing performance and low route availability.

name: LNWR Claughton Class
bio: The Claughton Class, named after the LNWR's chairman at the time, was unfortunately compromised by the Crewe works being unable to build a large boiler.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}The Claughton Class, named after the LNWR's chairman at the time, was unfortunately compromised by the Crewe works being unable to build a large boiler.

name: GCR Robinson 9P
bio: Robinson's 9P was a four-cylinder express locotive introduced toward the end of his time at the GCR. Early versions suffered from high coal consumption due to narrow steam passages.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}Robinson's 9P was a four-cylinder express locotive introduced toward the end of his time at the GCR. Early versions suffered from high coal consumption due to narrow steam passages.

name: GCR Robinson 9Q
bio: The 9Q is a freight adaptation of the 9P, which had an exceptional turn of speed for a high tractive effort engine. It earnt the name "Black Pig" for its heavy coal consumption.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}The 9Q is a freight adaptation of the 9P, which had an exceptional turn of speed for a high tractive effort engine. It earnt the name "Black Pig" for its heavy coal consumption.

name: LNER U1
bio: The largest British steam locomotive ever built, the one-off U1 was designed by Sir Nigel Gresley as a banking engine for the Woodhead line. Although powerful it struggled to find a use after the Woodhead line was electrified, being scrapped in 1955.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}1.4 tiles{}{SILVER}The largest British steam locomotive ever built, the one-off U1 was designed by Sir Nigel Gresley as a banking engine for the Woodhead line. Although powerful it struggled to find a use after the Woodhead line was electrified, being scrapped in 1955.

name: LMS Beyer Garratt
bio: The LMS Beyer Garratt was the most-produced Garratt type locomotive, designed for hauling heavy freight. While they suffered from poor fuel efficiency and high maintenance requirements, they survived in service to the late 1950s.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}1.2 tiles{}{SILVER}The LMS Beyer Garratt was the most-produced Garratt type locomotive, designed for hauling heavy freight. While they suffered from poor fuel efficiency and high maintenance requirements, they survived in service to the late 1950s.

name: LNER Raven A2
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{SILVER}

name: LNER Thompson B1
bio: LNER's B2 was a mixed traffic locomotive, the early examples of which were named after breeds of antelope, with 61018 "Gnu" having the record for shortest name given to a British locomotive.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{SILVER}LNER's B2 was a mixed traffic locomotive, the early examples of which were named after breeds of antelope, with 61018 "Gnu" having the record for shortest name given to a British locomotive.

name: Brown, Boverie & Cie 18000
bio: Originally ordered by the GWR, the 18000 used a gas turbine to match the power output of the King Class. This resulted in it being unreliable and expensive to run.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Gas Turbine {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.7 tiles{}{SILVER}Originally ordered by the GWR, the 18000 used a gas turbine to match the power output of the King Class. This resulted in it being unreliable and expensive to run.

name: BR Class 03
bio: The Class 03 is a diesel-mechanical shunter, with a five speed manual gearbox driven through a fluid coupling. They were most useful in areas where the Class 08 was too large and heavy to operate.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}The Class 03 is a diesel-mechanical shunter, with a five speed manual gearbox driven through a fluid coupling. They were most useful in areas where the Class 08 was too large and heavy to operate.

name: Brush Class 53 "Falcon"
bio: Brush's "Falcon" was a prototype for a new generation of Type 4 locomotives, but advances in single-engined diesel made the Falcon with its two Maybach diesels obsolete at the point of introduction.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}Brush's "Falcon" was a prototype for a new generation of Type 4 locomotives, but advances in single-engined diesel made the Falcon with its two Maybach diesels obsolete at the point of introduction.

name: Brush HS4000 "Kestrel"
bio: The Brush "Kestrel" was a prototype high speed diesel locomotive. After a brief period of service in the UK it was sold to the Soviet Union, where it was re-gauged and used for testing.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}The Brush "Kestrel" was a prototype high speed diesel locomotive. After a brief period of service in the UK it was sold to the Soviet Union, where it was re-gauged and used for testing.

name: BREL Mk2 DBSO
bio: The DBSO is a driving trailer built from a converted Mk2F carriage. They were first used with Class 47 locomotives for a push-pull service that could be driven from either end.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}The DBSO is a driving trailer built from a converted Mk2F carriage. They were first used with Class 47 locomotives for a push-pull service that could be driven from either end.

name: CAF Mk5A DVT
bio: Mark 5A carriage sets include a driving van trailer, enabling loco-hauled trains to be driven from both ends.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.9 tiles{}{YELLOW}20% Bonus for long distance travel{}{SILVER}Mark 5A carriage sets include a driving van trailer, enabling loco-hauled trains to be driven from both ends.

name: Cartic
additional_text: {SILVER}

name: Cravens Class 105
bio: The Class 105 had a long and hard life on British Railways, mostly around the Eastern Region. Sadly this meant few survived in a viable condition for preservation.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}2{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}1.3 tiles{}{SILVER}The Class 105 had a long and hard life on British Railways, mostly around the Eastern Region. Sadly this meant few survived in a viable condition for preservation.

name: Pressed Steel Class 117
bio: The Class 117 was built under licence by Pressed Steel, being a variant of the Class 116 built by BRCW Derby.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}3{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}2.1 tiles{}{SILVER}The Class 117 was built under licence by Pressed Steel, being a variant of the Class 116 built by BRCW Derby.

name: SR 4DD Double Decker
bio: SR's 4DD was an experiment to see if double deck multiple units could increase capacity. The internal layout was compromised by the British loading gauge, and it was slow to load at stations.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}750V DC {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}4{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}2.8 tiles{}{YELLOW}10% Penalty for long distance travel{}{SILVER}SR's 4DD was an experiment to see if double deck multiple units could increase capacity. The internal layout was compromised by the British loading gauge, and it was slow to load at stations.

name: GRC&W Class 128 Parcel Van
bio: The Class 128 was built specifically for carrying parcels by the Gloucester Railway Carriage and Wagon Company.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.8 tiles{}{SILVER}The Class 128 was built specifically for carrying parcels by the Gloucester Railway Carriage and Wagon Company.

name: Siemens Class 185 "Desiro"
bio: The Class 185 is a diesel version of the Siemens Desiro family. Each car has its own 6 cylinder engine, giving the unit high acceleration.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}3{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}2.3 tiles{}{SILVER}The Class 185 is a diesel version of the Siemens Desiro family. Each car has its own 6 cylinder engine, giving the unit high acceleration.

name: Bombardier Class 730/2 "Aventra"
bio: The 730/2 is the longer and faster variant of the Class 730 units built for West Midlands Trains, serving on their London Northwestern Railway routes over the West Coast Main Line.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}25kV AC {BLACK}Cars: {GOLD}5{}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}4.1 tiles{}{SILVER}The 730/2 is the longer and faster variant of the Class 730 units built for West Midlands Trains, serving on their London Northwestern Railway routes over the West Coast Main Line.

name: Metropolitan-Vickers Bo-Bo Locomotive
additional_text: {SILVER}

name: LU Q Stock
additional_text: {YELLOW}35% Penalty for long distance travel{}{SILVER}

name: LOR Electric Units
bio: These lightweight multiple units were built for the Liverpool Overhead Railway, a since closed elevated railway operating around the Liverpool docks.
additional_text: #N/A

name: LU 1983 Stock
additional_text: {YELLOW}35% Penalty for long distance travel{}{SILVER}

name: GEC-Alsthom Class 374 "Eurostar e320"
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}25kV AC {}{SILVER}

name: Pony
bio: A smaller horse for a smaller railway.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Grass and hay {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}A smaller horse for a smaller railway.

name: Trevithick Locomotive
bio: Trevithick's "Pen-Y-Darren" locomotive was built for a experimental bet that one of Trevithick's stationary engines could pull a train were it mounted on wheels. While the bet was won, it cracked rails intended only for horse-drawn wagons and was returned to service as a stationary engine afterward.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.5 tiles{}{SILVER}Trevithick's "Pen-Y-Darren" locomotive was built for a experimental bet that one of Trevithick's stationary engines could pull a train were it mounted on wheels. While the bet was won, it cracked rails intended only for horse-drawn wagons and was returned to service as a stationary engine afterward.

name: George England "Princess"
bio: "Princess" was the first locomotive on the Ffestiniog Railway, going through multiple rebuilds and serving on the railway until its eventual closure in 1946.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.5 tiles{}{SILVER}"Princess" was the first locomotive on the Ffestiniog Railway, going through multiple rebuilds and serving on the railway until its eventual closure in 1946.

name: Fletcher Jennings "Talyllyn"
bio: "Talyllyn" was delivered to the Talyllyn railway as an 0-4-0, but converted to 0-4-2 after a few years to improve riding quality. It was retired in 1945, but refurbished in the late 1950s and returned to preservation service.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}"Talyllyn" was delivered to the Talyllyn railway as an 0-4-0, but converted to 0-4-2 after a few years to improve riding quality. It was retired in 1945, but refurbished in the late 1950s and returned to preservation service.

name: Fletcher Jennings "Dolgoch"
bio: "Dolgoch" was the second locomotive built for the Talyllyn railway. The heavier and more powerful "Talyllyn" was used more often by the railway, meaning "Dolgoch" was in better condition when preservation began and was the sole running locomotive at first.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}"Dolgoch" was the second locomotive built for the Talyllyn railway. The heavier and more powerful "Talyllyn" was used more often by the railway, meaning "Dolgoch" was in better condition when preservation began and was the sole running locomotive at first.

name: Double Fairlie
bio: The double Fairlie design is iconic of the Ffestiniog Railway. After the success of the first, "Little Wonder", the railway continued to build Fairlie locomotives under licence. This continues into modern times with the latest, "James Spooner II" due for completion in 2021.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.5 tiles{}{SILVER}The double Fairlie design is iconic of the Ffestiniog Railway. After the success of the first, "Little Wonder", the railway continued to build Fairlie locomotives under licence. This continues into modern times with the latest, "James Spooner II" due for completion in 2021.

name: Hunslet 0-4-0ST "Alice"
bio: These small Hunslet tank engines were used as quarry locomotives. "Alice" worked at Dinorwic, being used as a source of spare parts afterward, before being restored in the late '80s and early '90s and now running on the Bala Lake Railway.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}These small Hunslet tank engines were used as quarry locomotives. "Alice" worked at Dinorwic, being used as a source of spare parts afterward, before being restored in the late '80s and early '90s and now running on the Bala Lake Railway.

name: Hudswell Clarke 4-8-0
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{SILVER}

name: Barclay Sons & Co. E Class
bio: The E Class is a small 0-4-0 well tank. One used by the RAF is preserved on the Talyllyn railway as "Douglas", named after second owner Douglas Abelson who donated it from his engineering firm.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}The E Class is a small 0-4-0 well tank. One used by the RAF is preserved on the Talyllyn railway as "Douglas", named after second owner Douglas Abelson who donated it from his engineering firm.

name: GWR Rheidol Tank
bio: Charles Collett designed these tank locomotives to replace worn-out engines on the Vale of Rheidol line. They became the last steam locomotives running on British Railways, up until the line became a heritage railway in 1989.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Steam {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}Charles Collett designed these tank locomotives to replace worn-out engines on the Vale of Rheidol line. They became the last steam locomotives running on British Railways, up until the line became a heritage railway in 1989.

name: Ruston and Hornsby 33/40HP
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {}{SILVER}

name: Ruston and Hornsby 44/48HP
bio: Ruston and Hornsby built diesel locomotives for small industrial lines, which would often only need a small locomotive for hauling goods short distances.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}Ruston and Hornsby built diesel locomotives for small industrial lines, which would often only need a small locomotive for hauling goods short distances.

name: Hunslet 0-4-0DM
bio: The Hunslet 0-4-0DM is powered by a Gardner 4LW engine and is typical of a narrow gauge locomotive used for engineering duties.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}The Hunslet 0-4-0DM is powered by a Gardner 4LW engine and is typical of a narrow gauge locomotive used for engineering duties.

name: John Bate "Toby"
bio: Talyllyn Railway volunteer John Bate built this small locomotive using the engine from a Austin Seven. The canopy was added later.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Petrol {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}Talyllyn Railway volunteer John Bate built this small locomotive using the engine from a Austin Seven. The canopy was added later.

name: Baguley-Drewry Diesel
bio: Larger and more powerful diesel shunters displaced steam from industrial lines as they were more economical to run. Even preservation railways keep some around for utility duties.
additional_text: {BLACK}Powered by: {GOLD}Diesel {}{BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}Larger and more powerful diesel shunters displaced steam from industrial lines as they were more economical to run. Even preservation railways keep some around for utility duties.

name: Incline car
bio: Early narrow gauge railways were used solely for freight, until the Ffestiniog Railway began carrying passengers in the 1860s. Early gravity railways used incline cars to deliver quarry workers swiftly to their place of work.
brake_text: {YELLOW}Preserved railway bonus: passengers pay more when hauled by old locomotives{}
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{YELLOW}Preserved railway bonus: passengers pay more when hauled by old locomotives{}{SILVER}Early narrow gauge railways were used solely for freight, until the Ffestiniog Railway began carrying passengers in the 1860s. Early gravity railways used incline cars to deliver quarry workers swiftly to their place of work.

name: Four-wheel carriage
bio: When narrow gauge began operating passenger services, carriages were simple, flat-sided vehicles build around wooden frames on a four-wheel chassis.
brake_text: {YELLOW}Preserved railway bonus: passengers pay more when hauled by old locomotives{}
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{YELLOW}Preserved railway bonus: passengers pay more when hauled by old locomotives{}{SILVER}When narrow gauge began operating passenger services, carriages were simple, flat-sided vehicles build around wooden frames on a four-wheel chassis.

name: Bogie carriage
bio: Later narrow gauge carriages increased in length where loading gauges allowed, using bogies to help negotiate tight curves.
brake_text: {YELLOW}Preserved railway bonus: passengers pay more when hauled by old locomotives{}
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.5 tiles{}{YELLOW}Preserved railway bonus: passengers pay more when hauled by old locomotives{}{SILVER}Later narrow gauge carriages increased in length where loading gauges allowed, using bogies to help negotiate tight curves.

name: Four-wheel brake carriage
bio: Brake vans were rarer on narrow gauge railways, but passenger services would typically have a guard's wagon which could also carry parcels.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}Brake vans were rarer on narrow gauge railways, but passenger services would typically have a guard's wagon which could also carry parcels.

name: Bogie brake carriage
bio: Larger and heavier carriages also meant larger and heavier guard's vans.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.5 tiles{}{SILVER}Larger and heavier carriages also meant larger and heavier guard's vans.

name: Open wagon
bio: An open wagon for carrying bulk cargo on narrow gauge railways.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}An open wagon for carrying bulk cargo on narrow gauge railways.

name: Mineral wagon
bio: Heavier mineral wagons allowed larger amounts of cargo to be carried.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}Heavier mineral wagons allowed larger amounts of cargo to be carried.

name: Flat wagon
bio: While many narrow gauge railways were quarry lines carrying bulk goods or slate, flat wagons were used for transporting equipment.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}While many narrow gauge railways were quarry lines carrying bulk goods or slate, flat wagons were used for transporting equipment.

name: Bolster wagon
bio: As per standard gauge practice, bolster wagons were used for carrying long, rigid cargo.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}As per standard gauge practice, bolster wagons were used for carrying long, rigid cargo.

name: Long Bolster
bio: Narrow gauge railways tend to use smaller vehicles capable of traversing tight turns, but the occasional larger wagon can be found on straighter routes.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.4 tiles{}{SILVER}Narrow gauge railways tend to use smaller vehicles capable of traversing tight turns, but the occasional larger wagon can be found on straighter routes.

name: Tank wagon
bio: With specialised equipment at stations, tank wagons made liquid cargo easier to handle than loading drums into open wagons.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}With specialised equipment at stations, tank wagons made liquid cargo easier to handle than loading drums into open wagons.

name: Livestock van
bio: A van for carrying livestock on narrow gauge railways.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}A van for carrying livestock on narrow gauge railways.

name: Wooden-framed van
bio: Like their larger counterparts, narrow gauge railways built many vans for carrying piece goods.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}Like their larger counterparts, narrow gauge railways built many vans for carrying piece goods.

name: Gunpowder van
bio: Gunpowder vans carried explosives to the quarries served by narrow gauge railways. This example has solid iron construction.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}Gunpowder vans carried explosives to the quarries served by narrow gauge railways. This example has solid iron construction.

name: Iron-framed van
bio: Later vans used iron frames to increase their strength and enable running at faster speeds.
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{SILVER}Later vans used iron frames to increase their strength and enable running at faster speeds.

name: Dandy wagon
bio: Early gravity railways sent cargo downhill with horses riding in dandy wagons. At the bottom the horses would be unloaded and used to haul the empty train back up the hill.
brake_text: {YELLOW}Faster downhill speeds for horse-drawn trains (1 required per 2 horses){}
additional_text: {BLACK}Length: {GOLD}0.3 tiles{}{YELLOW}Faster downhill speeds for horse-drawn trains (1 required per 2 horses){}{SILVER}Early gravity railways sent cargo downhill with horses riding in dandy wagons. At the bottom the horses would be unloaded and used to haul the empty train back up the hill.
